“In a dizzying 24 hours, congressional Republicans announced two investigations into old controversies that centered on 2016 Democratic presidential nominee … It’s a tactical shift that has put Republicans on offense, with the vocal support of the president, and has strained the last vestiges of bipartisan comity that congressional investigators have worked to salvage as they attempt to get to the bottom of Russian misdeeds during the 2016 election and prevent future attacks.”

Trump’s response has been consistent — contempt and blame for Democrats — and he continued in that vein today.

Trump’s disdain for Clinton hasn’t slowed his effort to reshape the GOP, POLITICO’s Alex Isenstadt reports, with the president “squeezing out his enemies in the Republican Party — diminishing the power of the GOP establishment and reshaping his party in his own image.”

Elsewhere in President Trump’s orbit:

WIKI WILD: Alexander Nix, a data guru with Cambridge Analytica who worked with President Donald Trump’s campaign, reached out to WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange in an effort to get access to Hillary Clinton’s emails.

poster="http://v.politico.com/images/1155968404/201710/412/1155968404_5625205755001_5625136215001-vs.jpg?pubId=1155968404" true 45 After Dark: Clinton Nostalgia edition Meanwhile, the Trump campaign argued in court on Wednesday that WikiLeaks’ publication of apparently hacked emails was legal.

After yesterday’s revelation that the DNC and Hillary Clinton’s campaign were involved in funding research for a salacious dossier of allegations about President Donald Trump’s ties to Russia, Republicans seized on a chance to change narrative.

Story Continued Below

And it came during a week when Congressional Republicans already seemed to want to focus more on the vanquished Democratic nominee, POLITICO’s Kyle Cheney reports .
SUBSIDY FIGHT: A federal judge declined a request to force the Trump administration to pay for Obamacare insurance subsidies, saying it was not an immediate threat to consumers.
JEFF WON’T FLAKE: Arizona Sen. Jeff Flake says he won’t be vindictive toward President Trump’s agenda, even after excoriating him from the Senate floor this week.
Ambassador to New Zealand Scott Brown acknowledged that the State Department investigated him over “insensitive or inappropriate” comments during a trip to Samoa.
: Meanwhile, the Trump campaign argued in court on Wednesday that WikiLeaks’ publication of apparently hacked emails was legal.
POORLY BALANCED: President Trump’s approval rating is at the lowest point it has ever been in Fox News’ new poll.
He called the dossier a “disgrace” while also hinting that he knew which Republicans were behind it, too.
